main event: On the evening of 30 July 1950, near St. John's, Newfoundland, several witnesses reported observing an unconventional aircraft maneuvering in the sky, described as bright and blue in color and leaving behind a brilliant stream of flame.
interesting points: The object was reported to be round in shape, about the size of a house, and gave off a brilliant light, visible for approximately 10 seconds.
Witnesses observed a deep blue glow in the sky, followed by a roaring sound, further adding to the mysterious nature of the sighting.
One witness reported seeing an object resembling a lighted torch streaking across the sky at a terrific speed, seemingly striking the ground or passing behind a hill.

The consensus of opinion was that the aircraft did not attain any extraordinary speed while in flight, with some witnesses even speculating that the object may have struck the ground in the vicinity of the air force base.

A military official, while positive that the sighting was a meteor, described the object as the most beautiful meteor he had ever seen while another witness indicated that it did not appear to be a meteor but disappeared as if behind a transmitter site.
witnesses: various witnesses including military personnel and residents of St. John's, Newfoundland
photographs: no photographs available in the report
